sect1.title: Settings and Audiences for Health Behavior Change
sect1.para: Public health professionals work around the world, in a variety of settings, including schools, worksites, government and nongovernmental organizations (including voluntary health organizations), medical and dental settings, and communities and community organizations. Even professionals not in the health field may influence health behaviors. Applications in the book offer many examples of different settings, health problems, and the role of theory in addressing them. During the past century, and more specifically during the past few decades, the scope and methods of health behavior change strategies have broadened and diversified dramatically. This section briefly reviews the range of settings and audiences for health behavior change today.

listitem.para: Settings: Health behavior interventions can occur almost anywhere. Seven major settings are particularly relevant to contemporary health behavior: schools, communities, worksites, healthcare settings, where people live, where people worship, the consumer marketplace, and the communications environment. Policy interventions may be delivered at the level of governments and other organizations. Examples of types of interventions in these settings are shown in Table 1.1.

Audiences: For health behavior change interventions to be effective, strategies should be designed with an understanding of the recipients, or audiences, their health, cultural context, and social characteristics, and their beliefs, attitudes, values, skills, and past behaviors. These audiences consist of people who may be reached as individuals, in groups, through organizations, as communities or sociopolitical entities, or through some combination of these. They may be health professionals, clients, people at risk for disease, or patients. Table 1.2 describes four dimensions along which the potential audiences can be characterized: social determinants of health (Adler et al., 2016; Centers for Disease Control, 2023; World Health Organization, 2023c), ethnic or racial background, life cycle stage, and disease or at‐risk status.

Settings for Health Behavior Interventions

Capacity‐building among school personnel (e.g., teachers)
Inclusion/interventions through existing or new curricula

Total Worker Health: Integration of workplace safety with health promotion
Workplace wellness and well‐being programs to change lifestyles
Programs for high‐risk patients and their families and caregivers
In‐service training for healthcare providers
Community engagement and community mobilization for program design and delivery

Choice architecture to make the easy choice the healthy choice (Chapter 20)
Counter “commercial determinants” such as promotion of unhealthy lifestyles (e.g., fast food or tobacco)
Use social marketing to encourage healthy lifestyle (Chapter 21)

Participatory communication technologies such as social media have been successfully used to promote health (Chapter 22)
Mass media campaigns for countering misinformation, defining health, and promoting healthy behaviors (Chapter 17)

Features of Audiences for Health Behavior Interventions

row.entry: Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) (Adler et al., 2016; WHO, 2023c)

listitem.para: Nonmedical factors that influence health outcomes; conditions in which people are born, grow, work, live, and age
Wider forces and systems shaping the conditions of daily life
Include income, education, housing, access to health care
As social constructs, closely aligned with SDOH
Neighborhood racial distribution
Segregation, structural racism
Inequities in morbidity and mortality, often gender‐specific
Developmental perspectives help guide intervention design and delivery
Life‐course perspective is often aligned with determinants of behaviors, e.g., sense of vulnerability/invulnerability
In the U.S., the aging population, including the very old, is increasing disproportionately
Risk factors often prompt greater use of health care
Patients’ needs vary depending on the nature of their health problems—for example, acute or chronic, disabling or limiting
